ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Was birth premature?
Weeks premature
Respondent detail
Notes: 1 = Mother; 2 = Father; 3 = Other relative or custodial adult; 4 = Teacher or caregiver; 5 = Other specialist; 6 = Other; 7 = Child; 8= Spouse; 999 = Not available

ElementDescription: When your child is playing with a toy, does he/she look at you and then back at the toy?
If you look at and point to a toy out of your child's reach, does your child look at the toy?
When your child is happy, does he/she smile or laugh and look at you at the same time?
When your child is upset or frustrated, does he/she express this clearly with facial expression, sounds, or words?
How often does your child get upset or frustrated each day?
When your child is upset, does he/she calm down easily (within a few minutes)?
When you are with your child, is your child comfortable interacting with unfamiliar people or new situations?
When your child is afraid, does he/she seek comfort from you?
Does your child clearly let you know when he/she needs help (for example, wants you to open a container)?
Does your child clearly let you know when he/she wants an object  that is out of reach?
Does your child let you know that he/she does not want something that you are offering him/her?
Does your child greet you when you come in the room or leave?
Does your child reach out to give you a hug or kiss?
Does your child try to get your attention when you are busy doing something, such as when you are talking with an adult or preparing a meal?
If your child does something that is funny and you laugh, does your child do it again for the attention?

Does your child try to get you to notice interesting objects, not to get you to do anything with them, but just to get you to look at them (for example, show you an object or point to a picture in a book)?
Does your child try to draw your attention to exciting or unexpected things, such as a pop-up toy or something falling down?
If you can't figure out what your child is trying to communicate, does your child try again or use a different way to get his/her meaning across?
Does your child use gestures that are easily understood by others, such as giving objects, showing objects, pointing, and waving?
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? give an object to you
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? show an object to you {i.e., by extending arm but not releasing object)
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? push an object away
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? raise arms to be picked up
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? reach with an open hand toward an object
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? wave "hi" or "bye bye"
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? point to an object or a picture that is within reach
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? point to an object or a picture out of reach
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? shake head to indicate "no"
Which of the following gestures have you seen your child use? nod head to indicate "yes"
Does your child use sounds to communicate both pleasure and discomfort?

Children use sounds to communicate in vocal play before they use sounds in words. Does your child use a variety of different consonant sounds, such as ba, ga ta and da either in vocal play or in words?
If so, which of the following sounds have you heard your child use, either in vocal play or in words?
Notes: /m/ as in "mamamama" or "mama" or "moo"; /n/ as in "nununu" or "no no"; /b/ as in "babababa" or "bibo" or "boo" or "bye bye"; /d/ as in "dodododo" or "daddy"; /g/ as in "googoo" or "gone gone"; /w/ as in "woowoo" or "weewee" or "wagon"; /I/ as in "lalala" or "balloon" or "little"; /y/ as in "yayaya" or "yum yum" or "you"; /s/as in "sasasa" or "sock" or "kiss"; /sh/ as in "shashasha" or "hush" or "shoe"

ElementDescription: Does your child put sounds together, either in vocal play or words (for example, "baba", "mamama", "dada","bye bye")?
Does your child use words to communicate that are understandable to you?
If so, which of the following words have you heard your child use (include approximations that you recognize, such as "nana" for banana or "baba" for bottle)?
Notes: mommy; daddy; baby; dog; kitty; bird; duck; eye; nose; moo; woof; grr (animal noise); peekaboo; bye bye; no; hi; all gone; uhoh; night night; outside; yum yum; vroom; ouch; up; bottle; banana; ball; bath; book; car; cookie; juice; sock; keys; balloon; truck

ElementDescription: Does your child use words that are understandable to unfamiliar adults?
Does your child put two or more words together (for example, more cookie, daddy car, bye bye kitty)?
Does your child respond when you call his/her name (for example, by looking/turning head)?
Does your child respond appropriately to gestures (for example, giving you an object when you say "give it to me" while holding out your hand or while pointing to the object)?
Does your child understand words or short phrases when you use only words and do not use gestures?
If so, which of the following words does your child understand without gestures (i.e., if you say the word, your child will find the object or carry out the action)?
Notes: mommy; daddy; child's name; baby; kitty; dog; bird; nose; eyes; tummy; foot; hair; peekaboo; bye bye; no; hi; all gone; uh oh; night night; outside; eat; drink; hug; bite; bottle; bath; ball; book; diaper; car; juice; shoe; cup; keys; ballon; trucks

ElementDescription: Does your child show interest in playing with a variety of objects?
Does your child use a variety of common objects appropriately (for example, comb, spoon, toothbrush)?

"If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do with objects? comb or brush hair"
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do with objects? feed self with a spoon

If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do with objects? roll or throw a ball
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do with objects? push a toy vehicle
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do with objects? put toy telephone to ear
Does your child pretend to play with toys (for example, feed a stuffed animal, put a baby doll to sleep, put an animal figure in a vehicle)?
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? feed with a spoon
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? drink with a cup or bottle
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? comb or brush hair
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? cover with blanket
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? wash or wipe face with cloth
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? brush teeth with toothbrush
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? put on diaper
If so, which of the following actions have you seen your child do when playing with another person, a stuffed animal, or a doll? hug or kiss
Does your child pretend by putting two or more actions together in a sequence, such as stirring food and feeding doll or washing doll's face and covering doll with a blanket?
Does your child build or arrange toy objects (for example, build a tower of blocks, stack rings, put puzzle pieces together)?
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? take blocks out of container
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? put blocks in container
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? build a tower of blocks
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? put puzzle pieces together
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? stack rings on ring stacker without regard for order
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? put rings on ring stacker in order
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? hold crayon or marker and scribble on paper
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? draw shapes or patterns on paper
Which of these actions have you seen your child do? squeeze and bang playdough
"Which of these actions have you seen your child do? make shapes with playdough, such as hot dogs or pancakes"
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? turn pages
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? look at pictures
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? look at pictures and then look at you
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? point to pictures without being asked
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? point to pictures when asked
Which of these actions have you seen your child do with books? label pictures
How has your child's communication changed over the past few months?
List a few strengths or assets you observe in your child.
List any concerns you have about your child's development.
